Évaluation publiée le 24 avril 2017
decent concept, poor execution. a good puzzle game will give you all of the pieces you need to complete it, but not tell you how they go together. and when you figure out the answer, (at the very least) you feel like you accomplished something. i dont get that at all from this game. I found myself wandering around and trying to make sense of the environment, turning knobs and pushing buttons until i eventually found my way to the exit. there was no understanding of the level that led me to its completion, so upon completing the level, i didn't feel like i had earned it. think of it like a maze on a piece of paper, but all you can see of the maze is a small circle around your pen. you wind up taking every wrong turn in your hunt for the exit, and when you finally get there the only thought that crosses your mind is "well i had to get here eventually"

i though disoriented was just a clever title, but that's exactly how this game makes you feel. every button and knob looks the same, so it's difficult to keep track of all the puzzle elements, let alone which sections of the map are modified when something is changed. Theres nothing to associate sections of the map that move with their corresponding knob. this game would benefit greatly from some color coding (blue knob moves the blue section, green knob moves the green section, etc). another tool that would assist the players is a map of the level, like a scale version of the map that you can rotate and zoom in and out and whatnot, allowing the player to start the level with with at least some sense of direction, rather than happen across the puzzle elements one by one.

also, the free achievements for just loading the game is stupid.

Évaluation publiée le 11 décembre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

This is a 3D puzzle game in a similar style to games like The Bridge, Evo Explores and Monument Valley but there are two major differences:

  1. There are no optical illusions - no bridges appear over gaps when obscured, there's no mind-bending twisting of perspective or anything like that, it's all logical and mechanical.

  2. It's a first-person perspective. This makes a big difference in the way you play the levels because you can't get an overall view of the whole puzzle. It's like the difference between solving a maze from above or from within it.

The game involves walking along the catwalks of a 3D maze structure suspended in space to activate coloured waypoints and finally reach the exit gate to the next level. Curved corners change the direction of gravity so you can step over the edge to "fall" onto other catwalks. New mechanics are introduced as you progress such as nodes to rotate sections of catwalks, buttons to toggle the 'lights' on and off which make catwalk sections appear and disappear, and portals that allow you to "fall" to other sections of the puzzle. I don't think it has controller support but WASD/mouse works well. You find yourself constantly looking around to try and work out where you are and where you're going since the puzzle is constantly moving around you as you change your direction of gravity. Disoriented is the perfect name for it because that's how you feel most of the time.

Sound & Vision

The graphics are stark and functional with a no-frills monochrome environment apart from the coloured waypoint markers. Note: the chequered design in the Steam videos for the game has since been changed to plain white. Nothing wrong with that, it removes any distractions from the puzzle at hand. Likewise, the background tunes are the usual ambient sounds that accompany most games like this.

Performance

It's a minimal environment and runs well, no lag or glitches. There's fullscreen and windowed options but no in-game resolution options for windowed, and the default is quite small. I discovered the reason for this is because you can resize the window by simply dragging it like any other window, which is nice.

Windows only - I would have liked to play it in Linux.

Difficulty

The game mechanics are simple to grasp and no explanation or tutorial is necessary. The first half of the game I found easy but then there's a sudden spike and it becomes very difficult. Part of the difficulty, as I mentioned before, is due to the fact that you can't get an overview of the whole puzzle. You activate a button or node and you have to look around you to see what's happening and maybe move away a bit to get a better angle. It makes you feel immersed in the puzzle as if you're part of it. I like that.

Another aspect to the difficulty of this game is that it's new and unpopular so right now there are no guides or walkthroughs whatsoever. If you get stuck, you're on your own! This can be a good or bad thing depending on your view :)

Steam

No trading cards yet. 6 achievements, all progress-related. Cloud support. Leaderboards recently introduced which are quite sparse at time of writing.

Value

First off I must stress that the pricing is fair and justified. It's a good quality game with a unique concept and I would recommend it at full price.

However, the author has openly said that he's had hardly any sales and I suspect I know the reason why. With 23 levels, when all is said and done this is a short puzzle game. Short puzzle games attract a certain type of player - I should know because I'm one of them. We have a voracious appetite for these games and buy lots of them, but we are accustomed to paying $1-$2. Anything higher tends to fly above the radar. It's my opinion that the game would do much better if the author swallowed his pride and reduced it to $2 and I think the volume sales would then make this a more lucrative prospect for him.

Verdict

It's a nice short minimalistic puzzler to challenge your spatial awareness. Very enjoyable. The author says there are more levels coming soon and I look forward to them.
 
JimDeadlock

Évaluation publiée le 18 juin 2017
Like so many negative reviews, I want to like this game. The puzzle concept was interesting - I've played The Bridge and Mindcubes before and found this a similar kind of gravity/perspective twisting puzzle and was looking forward to getting into it. It's bare-bones graphics, but that works (you wouldn't want too much clutter on the screen as it's a challenge enough to figure out which way will be up when you turn a corner). I didn't have any of the issues others have had with achievement-spam and clunky controls (playing on PC with keyboard and mouse only - seemed alright).

What wigged me out was that the game gave me pretty hardcore motion sickness after only a few minutes. I'm not prone to this normally (get it occassionally in cars if I'm trying to read a lot), haven't had it from a game before, but with this one I had to go lie down and close my eyes for a bit before I could do anything else. I tried coming back to the game after a little while and it happened again. The controls are WASD to move, the mouse directs the camera so you can look around. I've played games before that had similar control setups and haven't felt sick so it might be something about the perspective shift and constant looking 'up' that triggered the motion sickness for me. This is the sole reason why I'm giving a negative review - so far as I could tell from the brief time I could play it was otherwise exactly my kind of game (love puzzlers). I just didn't get to play it much. Not really the devs fault, but it's a shame and perhaps a useful warning to others.

So I can't tell you what the later levels are like at all! First few levels didn't throw me in the deep end too much, took a little bit to get the hang of it but not more than two levels. There's very little instruction, but you don't need much. Each level took just a minute or two at the start, though I can see how it would get pleasently harder.

Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2019
Definitely a nice puzzle game, probably not worth the full price given the minimalistic/limited experience it offers to the gamer, but still overall good.
The settings screen first of all is awesome - finally we can adjust all the bars related to controls, sensitivity, music and graphics, not something that one can find everywhere these years..
The game offers only 30 levels that have an awesome difficulty progression, though as I wrote above it can be a little downside regarding the potential replayability of the game itself and its duration - hence I suggest you to buy it on discount or in a bundle.
Set in a minimalistic, ethereal black and white world, you'll be in control on a first-person prospective of some kind of guy (I mean, there's footsteps there! xD) and you'll have to manage lots of things at the same time - WASD keys, the mouse (adjust the sensibility as you please) to move the camera, the TAB key to switch it in order to have a broad view of the level (and to zoom if you like) and so on.
The game is totally set in a 3D environment, meaning that you'll be climbing lots of stairs and tiles and you'll have to be aware not to fall off the other screen, it's not that easy :P
Though, there are lots of checkpoints (well, with the C hotkey you can actually even -create- your own ones!) and you'll never get penalties or similar things, you can try as many times as you want to pass some kind of point in a level restarting some steps before.. this is fundamental in order not to create frustration, since even the first level pose quite a challenge while you're getting accustomed to the 3D environment,
As minimalistic as it is, the game's lovely. It poses serious challenges to anyone who likes this genre, and it's greatly realized - the customization options too give the player the possibility to set the controls as he pleases, and the game has no bugs or whatever negative.
Just, it lacks of replayability - once you complete a level, you're not that tempted to re-play everything over again. And even if the 30 levels are hard and challenging, the game will be over in a few hours (or days, play it step by step =P). Not that this is a downside, I just recommend to wait for a discount given it 3,50€ starting price.
Anyways, the levels are really greatly realized. Going deep in the game you'll start of course to meet new obstacles - portals, rotating platforms and so on. Played with mouse and keyboard, it's really pleasant and funny (I can't say anything about the partial controller support, but I don't really imagine this game as something meant to be played without a keyboard).
I'm happy this game is so popular and it has already lots of positive reviews, so I'm just adding mine here. If you like challenging first-person 3D puzzle games, or hard puzzle games in general, this game definitely is for you, even if maybe its 30 levels don't justify the full price.
Good job, definitely, anyways!

I feel forced to review this game because of all the negative comments I think are not fair. Okay, I got the game on a sale at 0.99€ so it was a good deal but still, I think it would remain good at 3.99€ without a doubt.

Some people say that the controls are bad. What? These are very basic and standard first person shooter controls. Nothing special here, and it works quite well.

Some people complain about the 666 achievements. Dunno why it's here, seems like a bug, but I don't care. Why would I?

Very appreciable.

Небольшая (30 уровней) минималистичная головоломка на пространственное мышление. Нужно всего-то дойти до выхода и не свалиться в пропасть. Полом считается любая поверхность, на которой ты стоишь, а "поворачивающие" ступени положение пола меняют.

По большому счёту, любая из головоломок решается в уме. С одним "но" - на уровне есть поворачивающие рычаги (которые действуют на определённые куски уровня) и переключатели (которые меняют "день" на "ночь" и обратно, делая доступными разные временные - затемнённые - куски). И заранее неизвестно ни что поворачивается, ни что появится при переключении. Но после того как ты узнал действие всех активных элементов на уровне, остаётся только решить уровень мысленно - и пройти ногами.

Если ты упал - уровень ресетится на начало. Но есть возможность поставить контрольную точку - тогда он будет ресетиться на эту точку. Разумеется, нужно быть внимательным, чтобы не ставить точки, когда уже зашёл в безвыходный тупик.

Проходится часов за десять легко, но и стоит немного. Рекомендую.

660개는 게임 시작과 함께 달성이 되어버리는데 서비스로 제공해주는 도전과제로 보인다.

게임 중반 이후로 가면 클리어가 쉽지 않은 편으로 3~5시간은 플레이해야 클리어가 가능할 것으로 보인다.

Évaluation publiée le 28 aout 2017
In good puzzle games, the player can look at a puzzle without interacting with it, and solve it in their head completely before starting to solve it in the game. Despite having so much potential, Disoriented is not a good puzzle game. There is no signage to connect inputs to outputs, so you're left to guess what controls what and then forced to memorize it. There are moving components and components that pop in and out of existence, but there are no outlines/dashed lines or indications of their possible states, so you have to test everything with trial and error. The hardest puzzles in the game are merely fake difficulty caused by this inability to solve the puzzle in your head first - you have to try everything until something works. There are also trapping situations that don't seem like trapping situations at first, since you can still move about and interact with things. Then you realize you were supposed to orient something some way or press a button first, and have to start the level over. There are no loading screens, which is much appreciated, but there is a lot of unnecessary distance to travel back and forth, and the sprint key merely brings your movement speed up from a crawl to a slow walk.

I don't think this game is worth the price. There are better puzzle games for the same price or cheaper. I admire the visual quality of this game, but the actual gameplay doesn't hold up.

Évaluation publiée le 24 septembre 2017
Fun, fairly short puzzle game. Does a decent job of helping you get used to gameplay mechanics - the first time you see them, they aren't too difficult to use correctly. The gameplay video actually shows you all the mechanics in the game: 1) walking up a curve changes which direction is down, 2) there a switches that piece a part of the level, 3) there are toggle switches to change between night and day and there are platforms that disappear/appear because of that, and 4) there are teleporters. The levels do a good job of putting these mechanics together in interesting ways.

Biggest dislike is that the run button doesn't increase your speed by very much.

Ich finde Disoriented ein wirklich klasse Spiel. Es gibt andere Spiele wie Puzzle Dimension, Paralax oder auch Tri, die ein ähnliches Spielprinzip benutzen. Wenn man sucht, findet man schon in dem Computerspiel Prey (2006) Elemente, die dieses Spiel auch verwendet.

Dabei muß man sich auf einer Konstruktion bewegen bei der unten ist, wo die "Füsse" hinzeigen. Knöpfe und Schalter verändern die Konstruktion und schalten Wege frei oder versperren sie.

Nachteilig an dem Spiel finde ich, das es insgesamt doch zu wenige Level gibt. Mehr Level wären schön.

Évaluation publiée le 7 janvier 2019
Appropriately named, Disoriented is a thoroughly confusing puzzle platformer. The thought process becomes more and more demanding, especially approaching the last few of the 30 total levels. So much so it borders on frustration. Not only is it required to grasp the 3D spatial shifts, the puzzles also force the player to memorise the moving platforms and their respective switches.

The game looks a lot like Antichamber with its basic black and white rendering and some sparse drops of colour. These few drops prove to be quite important for the puzzles. The interactive spots, i.e. switches, buttons and portals, are small and look the same. However, some otherwise irrelevant plants with differing colours are placed in fixed positions and can be an immense help when it comes to recognising and tracing the structure of the level.

What makes the puzzles even more intricate is the fact that the platforming part also encompasses routes taken off the beam paths. While jumping up or across the beams isn't possible, dropping down is frequently, if not most of the time, a major part of the solution.

Disoriented is trickier than expected. It doesn't strictly follow the usual puzzle conventions and offers exercise to agonise over.

Really fun for the first hour! And then it feels like doing three-dimensional calculus homework. It's nice that you can progress step-by-step by exploring every option until you've exhausted them all. I assure you that you will experience a sudden spike in difficulty. If you are a mathematics major or diehard Portal fan, then I recommend this game. Is it worth $5.49..? No. The art and music are lacking but there's relaxing ambience and I'd certainly recommend buying it on sale to practice your reasoning skills. I got three hours of gameplay! There is a sense of satisfaction from beating the harder levels but there are not enough large levels! You can try to beat your friends' times but I have no friends so I think the game is worth $4. If you find the geometry too confusing, don't worry because you can usually beat a level by trial and error and there are no red herrings. I would like to see more levels.

1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 mars 2021
Imaginez une structure complexe flottant dans le vide dans laquelle le haut et le bas deviennent relatifs mais qu'il faut traverser pour atteindre la sortie et accéder à la suivante. Bienvenue dans Disoriented!


Durant les 30 niveaux, on se déplace sans pouvoir ni sauter ni escalader mais en pouvant se laisser tomber vers une partie inférieure de la structure. On peut actionner des interrupteurs qui vont apparaître/disparaître certaines zones et d'autres qui font pivoter des sections de la structure.

Tout cela semble simple mais après une douzaine de niveaux pour intégrer tranquillement tous les principes de gameplay, je dois vous prévenir que ça se complique ensuite très sérieusement. Ce n'est pas un walk sim avec un parcours évident à suivre comme semblent le laisser croire le début du jeu. Autant le dire clairement, ce n'est pas un jeu facile car rien n'est fait pour aider le joueur à qui on ne donne jamais aucune instruction (d'où le fait que l'absence de VF n'a absolument aucun impact).

En réalité, Disoriented est un casse-tête exigeant qui propose un défi compliqué demandant réellement de la réflexion pour comprendre comment tracer son chemin.
Il est souvent difficile d'avoir une vision globale de sa situation sans se déplacer et perdre de vue notre emplacement actuel et il est compliqué de s'orienter dans un environnement avec si peu de repères évidents, même si on peut switcher sur une caméra qui permet d'observer avec davantage de recul. Les graphismes épurés facilitent heureusement la lisibilité des environnements.
Il est réellement nécessaire d'observer attentivement, d'expérimenter de nombreuses manipulations et surtout de bien se concentrer pour comprendre ce qu'il faut faire, de repérer les effets de nos actions et identifier à quoi ça va nous servir (et surtout à quel moment) après avoir effectué plusieurs aller-retours à travers le niveau.

Bien que la difficulté soit bien présente, il est malgré tout reposant de se promener dans cet environnement à l'ambiance paisible qui bouleverse nos repères. C'est un plaisir de prendre le temps de chercher comment atteindre la sortie.

Je précise que je n'ai pas encore entièrement terminé le jeu au moment d'écrire ces lignes.



Un bon plan à petit prix qui va ravir les vrais amateurs de casse-têtes.

12.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2019
82 рубля за покупку, 113 МБ занимаемого пространства и 12 часов на прохождение. Вполне хорошее соотношение для маленькой игры с ценником как у отборного молока марки "Простоквашино". Однако не спешите оценивать по моему примеру, ведь я старался вытянуть из игры максимум удовлетворения процессом. Поэтому смотрим объективно!

В Disoriented есть тридцать уровней, которые по логике вещей не должны затянуть вас дольше чем на вечер. Это ошибочное мнение, так как даже прохождения у людей, именуемых "спидраннерами", занимало тридцать шесть 36 минут. Да, если посмотреть видео в руководствах, можно пройти практически за 2/3 часа. Но я этого не сделал, поэтому посмотрите сколько пришлось мучиться методом тыка. И конечно, оцените как люди проходили игру по обзорам: у кого меньше часа - однозначно воспользовался запретной техникой, обычным сообразительным людям добавьте от двух до 5 часов, ну а остальным скажите "спасибо" за их терпеливость. Всё же, немногие согласятся столько провести времени.

Сами уровни представляют геометрическую головоломку, где необходимо вертеть, крутить, и перемещаться под разными углами в лабиринте линий. Примечательно отсутствие физики в том смысле, что нет определенной гравитации, кроме установленной самой игрой. То ли магия, то ли неотличимая от магии технология. В любом случае, изменение пространства просто так не обойдётся для вашего вестибулярного аппарата, и после нескольких придирчивых заходов, могут ощущаться первые порывы покинуть "место исследователя". Будут встречаться поворотные кристаллы, лестницы с изменением плоскости движения, кнопка смены суток, а также телепорты. Всё это ближе к концу обретёт форму тотального издевательства, так что придётся много думать.

Стилистика игры минималистична, насколько это в принципе возможно: никаких смешанных цветовых тонов, строго очерченные линии предметов, строгое нахождение предметов в центре, голое окружение из блоков, полный ноль относительно определения пространства. Глазу не за что уцепиться, кроме небольших деталей. Благодаря этому вы можете почувствовать какой-то высокий смысл м-материй... Если вы любите размышлять об этом без всякой на то причины... Ладно, подобные мысли отбросим. Во всяком случае, скажу о визуальной пустоте атмосферы. При учёте вида от первого лица, крайне нейтральное зрелище.

Музыка здесь это тихий, незаметный амбиент, без грозных и пугающих струн, без затяжных и смачных завываний, лишь небольшие редкие нотки чего-то пролетающего в воздухе. Аура, наверно.

Если кто покупает за достижения, то здесь они довольно просты. Никаких напряжных или сложных. Всего лишь и надо, что посадить 60 растений и пройти все 30 уровней в общей сложности. За это получаете шесть достижений, а также статус идеальной игры.

Итого, дезориентирующая игра-головоломка со стерильными условиями и основной зацепкой в качестве геймплея. Разбираться самостоятельно муторно, но интересно. На реиграбельность игра не претендует, особого смысла в себе не таит, зато будет хороша как ещё одно пополнение пройденных полностью игр.

Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2016
This is an excellent 3D puzzle game that takes simple mechanics and makes use of them in mind bending ways. In some aspects it strongly reminds me of The Bridge. In particular, the atmosphere is very similar making use minimalistic graphics that combine exceptionally with the puzzles. As in The Bridge which direction is up changes. However, rather than making use of a 2D world filled with illusions, it uses a first person perspective in a 3D environment. This leads to simple mechanics quickly turning into difficult problems to solve as your perspective changes and you fight to visualize the 3D solution. In addition, one particular mechanic introduced in the later puzzles (#17) makes for some very interesting problems.

The two wishes I have for the game:
  1. Linux support - As a predominately Linux gamer I would love to see this on the Linux platform, however it is well worth booting up windows to play this.
  2. More levels - At the time of writing there appears to be new levels in the future, but I wanted to include this because the ground work has been laid for a large number of possible puzzles. The puzzles were great and I would love to see more of them making use of these exceptional mechanics. Edit: Some additional levels were added, but even more could be easily developed. Maybe a level creation tool could be developed/released to allow community developed levels.

Overall, if you like puzzle games this is definitely one to pick up and spend time with some mind twisting puzzles (at a very reasonable price).

Évaluation publiée le 3 juillet 2017
Puzzle-game assez sympathique, au style graphique certes minimaliste, mais au gameplay intéressant et très bien exploité. Dans Disoriented, tout est question de perspective - et donc de gravité, dans une certaine mesure. L'objectif est d'atteindre la sortie en passant d'une surface plane à une autre, déplacement qui ne sera possible que dans deux cas : soit vous tombez de la première sur la seconde, soit celles-ci sont reliées par une pente légèrement arrondie (comprenez par là que, si seule une arête les sépare, vous ne pourrez passer de l'une à l'autre).

Le jeu comporte 30 niveaux, d'une difficulté progressive, au fil desquels sont introduites trois mécaniques supplémentaires : un piédestal surmonté d'une pierre bleue qui, chaque fois que vous l'activerez, fera pivoter une partie du décor ; un bouton permettant d'alterner entre jour et nuit, ce qui fera apparaître/disparaître certaines plateformes ; enfin, un couple de miroirs fonctionnant à la manière des portails du célébrissime jeu de Valve - en d'autres mots, entrez par l'un et ressortez par l'autre. Tout ceci est exploité de concert, d'une façon plutôt habile, il faut bien l'admettre, notamment grâce aux phases d'apprentissage.

Aucun bug ni aucun souci de maniabilité en ce qui me concerne (à la manette), pas plus que de motion sickness d'ailleurs. Quant aux quelques 600 succès - d'un intêret discutable, je vous le concède -, soyons lucides : ils ne sont qu'une manière supplémentaire d'attirer le chaland. Mais comme Disoriented propose globalement un contenu de qualité, je ne vois pas de raison véritable de le pénaliser.

Edit (06/05/22) : Le jeu ne propose plus que 6 succès, ce qui n'est pas un mal, au contraire. Merci @ Axel de me l'avoir fait remarquer.

Verdict : 3,5/5 - Ce qui est bien, mais pas top.

Mechanically the game is very simple and the difficulty is definitely in wrapping your head around the problem and coming up with the solution.
Looks is nothing to write home about but it isn't ugly so it does what it needs to.
Performance and loadtimes are superb and it should hopefully run on just about any potato.

As of writing this I have 5 or 6 levels left to do out of a total off 30. Personally the difficulty could have ramped up quicker but it has so far been a nice and fun experience.

Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2023
Disoriented is a wacky puzzle game. Where up and down do not remain up and down as you rotate the world around.

The game plays in first person mode, and as such you can't easily see the whole map and you only see it from your own perspective. Using stairs rotates the world and after a bit it will be, as the name suggests, quite disorientating.

The game only has a few mechanice; walking, stairs (rotates the map), doorknops (rotates a small piece of the map). switches (adds/remove a small part on the map) and plants (you can water them for an achievment, they don't seem to do anything besides that). And as such the game is easy to learn, but as the levels progress, hard to master.

The game is quite fun to play around with. Simple and minimalistic but fun.
However, the game has a major flaw. There is no safe system (exiting the game means loss of ALL progress). The game combats this by having every level unlocked from the beginning so you can manualy continue where you left. If you want the achievments you need to play the whole game in one go. A bit of a shame, but I still liked the game.

Полагаю, разработчик вдохновлялся игрой Antichamber, так как белые угловатые конструкции с ломающими голову постройками редко где ещё встретишь. И лучше бы им быть дополнением к той игре.

Если бы объекты отличались цветом и обозначались места исчезающих мостов, то сложность состояла бы лишь в определении порядка нажатия на переключатели.

Сомнительное удовольствие от процесса, в котором "проглядеть" решение как никогда легко. И от этого только скучнее.
Можно представить, что здесь напрягается память, но заучивать расположение объектов в одноразовых картах как-то и не хочется.

Эта поделка представляет из себя лишь необычную демку и все интересные элементы из нее (переплетенные проходы и передвижение по всем поверхностям) лучше выглядели бы как маленький эпизод в другой игрушке "без правил", нежели набор из 30 скучнейших уровней за 82 рубля.

5/10
Единственная причина, по которой я поставил игре положительную оценку - разработчик попытался обновить игру, хоть уже и думал удалить из магазина.

Évaluation publiée le 20 novembre 2017
Игра оправдывает своё название, тебя дезориентирует на первом же уровне. Если вы не боитесь упасть с перехода между другими такими же переходами, висящими, черт знает где, в бездну, и владеете пространственным воображением, любите поломать голову в поисках пути, петляющему в пространстве... то вам в эту игру.

Бегать по некому лабиринту Эшера в простом виде с поворотами на 90, 180 или 270 градусов в разных плоскостях, это то ещё удовольствие, можно заработать тошноту от несоответствия сигналов от среднего уха и видимого на экране. А тут ещё надо прыгать с высоты на иногда плохо видимый пятачок внизу.
Разглядывать пройденный путь вниз башкой, то есть висящий над головой, и соориентироваться куда дальше идти в висящих так переходах под разными углами... что-то у меня от пары уровней начинала голова болеть.
А так хорошая головоломка и вроде недорогая. Иногда надо использовать рычаги и кнопки чтобы изменить ориентацию переходов и открыть новые пути скрытые в "темноте".
Я думал, что игра будет похожа на Antichamber , но оказалось что игра гораздо минималистичней, но от этого не проще. Но, кажется, идея этой игры, ноги растут из указанной игры. Черно-белая палитра, минималистичное окружение, некоторые игровые фишки, всё указывает на источник вдохновления.

Игру порекомендовать можно для людей с хорошим вестибюлярным аппаратом, или играть на свежую голову.
Стереометрия 9 из 10. Один балл минус потому что Однообразно черно-белое, из-за этого иногда не понимаешь, был ты тут или нет.

Évaluation publiée le 29 novembre 2016
Before you get the wrong idea from this review, I should note that while I enjoyed the game, I felt I paid too much for it.

Disoriented is a first-person puzzle game that takes inspiration from Manifold Garden, Monument Valley, and possibly Hocus. The goal in each level is to reach the exit, which is simple enough. However, because in puzzles, things aren't always so simple, each level is a weird 3D stick model, where you are able to walk up walls by using the curved ramps.

Naturally, because this alone would still make it just a maze, the game later introduces some mechanics, like switches that change the layout of the level, and portals that drop you through them. The very much unique implementation of the latter is what really brings out the puzzle design in the last levels of the game.

True to its name, you do very much get disoriented when playing the game because of the core gameplay, given that you're constantly turning and that there is no objective "down" direction. (This is less of a problem in Manifold Garden, which uses a similar mechanic, but also uses the level's architecture to keep the player knowing what's what.) In any case, this is perhaps part of the charm of the game, but it does get in the way of the puzzle sometimes; especially when the platform you're trying to get your bearings with is blocked by some other platform, and you can't just move around it without falling into the endless void (which resets the level).

The game runs very smoothly, (which is indeed more than I can say for some Unity games I've played). I'm assuming this game was made in Unity, which I've heard is horrendous when it comes to performance, so props to the developer on that!

The game has 23 levels, which are all fairly short. As you can tell from the gameplay time listed here, I completed the game in 79 minutes, so you should expect this to be a 2- or maybe 3-hour experience; this game definitely does not overstay its welcome, and some of the levels are definitely memorable (which is much, MUCH more than I can say for games like Flow Match, Rotieer and Duplexer). Still, for the price I bought it at (3.39 GBP), it definitely feels too expensive; I personally feel a fairer price would have been 0.99 GBP. (I should probably re-evaluate my pricing criteria at some point, but not today.)

However, there's a reason for this; the developer is raising money for his other game project, for which this is basically a teaser. Considering that this game is at least in the upper half of games I've played, AND the developer is still updating the game with more music and leaderboards, I have faith in his next project and you should too. Hence, while I could refund this game, I won't. Because between overpaying for this good game and not-paying-at-all for it, I feel like I'd feel guiltier doing the latter.

In short, very good and short relaxing game, but still much pricier than other good games. Definitely buy this if it's on sale for 75% off or more, but above that, you make your own decisions.
 
edderiofer

Évaluation publiée le 4 mars 2018
Disoriented is a really fun brain-teaser puzzle game offering 30 levels of various 3D mazes where you have to figure out the right path to reach the level exit door.
In order to do this, you have to interact with the maze by rotating some of its beams, using portals, switching between night and day which makes some beams appear/disappear.
You can use the Tab key to vizualise the whole maze and plan your strategy to reach the exit.
You cannot jump, but you can drop to lower beams, and the originality of the game is that gravity works in the direction of where you stand, which makes it easy to lost track of where you are and want to go.
There is also the possibility to create a checkpoint by pressing the 'C' key which can save your current location before you attempt some change on the maze or in the case you would fail a drop for instance, but it was only really useful for me on the last levels.

I found the first 11 levels very easy, but after that, difficulty increases, and reaching the exit becomes trickier and trickier... Still, when I finally succeeded in completing all levels, I had just wished there were more...

I did not encounter any of the bugs some people had, so I guess they all got fixed now, but I played with a keyboard/mouse.

Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2018
A puzzle game where you crawl on surfaces of complex contructions built from blocks. It's somewhat close to Kulaworld on PS1, but in a minimalistic setting.

Pros:
- the game feels fresh and unique. If you were intrigued by the Moebius band as a kid, this game gives a similar feel as you get "disoriented" while traversing the surfaces of complex objects (and gravity force keeps rotating together with you)

So-so:
- minimalistic art with a chilling soundtrack may give it a low-budget feel for some but I actually liked the simplicity of presentation. It's somewhat like in Antichamber, just less stuff

♥♥♥♥:
- too few levels (just 25)
- in most levels you can press levers which rotate some blocks and connect different parts of the maze. Though this does make sense in a puzzle game, the fact that the level changes in hard-to-predict ways (it's never clear which effect a lever will have until you press it) makes the puzzle more of a trial-and-error experience. The authors added checkpoints and a bird's eye camera view which help a lot with solving, but even with a bird's eye view you can't plan your solution if multiple pieces of the maze can rotate. You end up crawling the maze piece by piece, just trying random directions, until, a dozen restarts later, you finally reach the exit. There is rarely a feel of accomplishment here, instead just tedium and relief. So, instead of a puzzle game where you concieve a solution, it's much closer to a messy, convoluted maze which is intentionally presented in an unfriendly way, making it even harder to solve.

Disoriented is a maze/puzzle game in a minimalistic setting. You could probably solve all its 25 level in an evening or two. For its very modest price, it's still worth it.

I'm a Steam curator, you can follow me

Évaluation publiée le 21 aout 2017
The game is fine. It's a good puzzle game with some interesting mechanics. There isn't a whole lot of content, though (only about 30 levels), though they can get pretty long and intricate - especially the later levels. I think the amount of content reflects the price pretty fairly.

So why don't I recommend the game? It has 666 achievements. 6 of those achievements are earned by playing the game and "finding" this game's version of collectibles; little plants that you click on to water them. They are not hidden in any way, and you are practically (if not literally) required to pass by them in order to beat the levels. The other 660 achievements from this game are pure spam. I earned all 660 of them when I first started the game in an annoying spam in the lower righthand corner. It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and it's clearly meant to get extra purchases from people who actually care about their achievements. It's a shame because it's a pretty good game otherwise.

UPDATE: The developers have removed the spammy achievements from the game. As a result, I now recommend it. Good job, BrickCream!

1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2023
A good concept executed well for the namesake - but perils in comparison to mightier machinations.

The balance of a good puzzle game rests in the shadows of the player's own mind - where the solutions are clear and obvious, but lingering just outside of the initial perceptions of fresh eyes.
Good puzzle games are obscure and cryptic to initially baffle players - but reveal their secrets once they have digested the puzzle elements and put them together.
Puzzle games, good ones, feel somewhat challenging and give a rewarding levity upon completion - something this game lacks.

I've played for under an hour, but I already feel that I'm done with the title - take this as you will.

While conceptually intriguing, the product is barebones and callow.
Puzzles will either play themselves out to the point of feeling like a breeze; not being a challenge more than a walking simulator.
OR - they are so needlessly convoluted and abstract that solving them gives no sense of joy or accomplishment, just a bitter sense that your time was squandered.

The price is very good, and if you like listening to podcasts - this is a nice way to engage your coil while you have something playing in the background.

~

TL;DR

4.5/10
Disoriented is a Serviceable game.
It throws you for a loop every now again, but in spite of its twists and turns - it fails to shake up your foundation in any meaningful way, and is a better fit for the garbage bin of your memory.

4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2020
There's a solid, interesting core to this puzzle game, but a few things keep me from recommending it. First, just inherent to the core concept of the game is that it definitely induces vertigo - so be careful if you struggle with simulation sickness - and weird default FoV settings add to this by distorting objects at the edges of the screen. Second, there seems to be some sort of optimization issue: when I run the game for a while (not sure if it has more to do with the time I leave it running or the number of levels I go through) it eventually starts using up so much CPU that it becomes almost unplayable. Closing and reopening the app seems to fix this, but when you add sudden frame drops (down to maybe ~10fps) to the already vertigo-inducing gameplay, it's liable to make even the usually-most-comfortable players a little physically ill.

All that said, if you have an iron stomach and find the core idea of the game interesting, you'll probably enjoy this!

6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2018
Disoriented - Отличная логическая игра, которая полностью соответствует своему названию. В игре закономерно отсутствует сюжет, и всё что требуется от игрока это пройти из начальный точки А, до конечной дверной точки Б. Вот только ходить нам придётся по своеобразному лабиринту Эшера, со своими изгибами, витиеватыми поворотами, в разных плоскостях и сторонах, помимо этого по мере прохождения уровней будут добавляться различные элементы в виде рычагов поворота платформ и переключателей света, для ещё большего логического мыслительного штурма. В игре отсутствует функция прыжков, поэтому исхитриться пройти левел по быстрому, сворачивая от прямолинейных описанных сценариев не получится. Кстати об уровнях, в игре их 30, не так много как хотелось бы, но с учётом того, что сложность прохождения идёт по нарастающей, каждый игрок найдёт себе свой интересный и заковыристый уровень по вкусу, ибо баланс полностью соблюдён и если поначалу вас знакомят с местной физикой игры, всё проходится непринуждённо, то в последних уровнях придётся изрядно напрягать извилины мозга чтобы пройти до логического завершения.

Сама игра выполнена в минилистическом стиле, с приятным музыкальным фоном, игрок не имеет жизней, поэтому в случаи неудачного решения, он всегда начинает с последнего удобного чекпойнта. Именно так созданы идеальные условия игры, особенно для тех кто любит немного разгрузиться и в непринуждённой, расслабляющей обстановке после рабочего дня провести парочку приятных досуговых вечеров.
Но самым главным плюсом игры является сами загадки и путь их решения. Каждый уровень не похож на предыдущий и обладает своим интересным логическим решением. Для успеха, необходимо не только внимательность, усидчивость, но и логические просчёты, а также проецирование и моделирование объектного пространства в разных плоскостях, в результате, после упорных попыток, когда загадка решается, получаешь неимоверное удовольствие от пути её решения и то, что ты смог сам во всём разобраться (Моё почтение автору за уровни 22 и 29, они правда удивительны и прекрасны по своему)
Игра, частенько мелькает в акциях, с приятной скидкой, поэтому точно брать для ценителей похожих жанров, скорее всего эта игра принесёт им удовольствие как от самого процесса хождения, так и от решаемых загадок.

Nie. Świetny pomysł, bardzo fajnie utrzymana strona wizualna i dźwiękowa, ale gra sama w sobie...? Co najwyżej przeciętna. Bardzo szybko zmieniła się z gry logicznej w grę typu "zapamiętaj który klocek teraz się obróci, ale po obróceniu ekranu o 270 stopni". Do połowy było jeszcze przyjemnie, ale reszta poziomów opierała się (przynajmniej w moim odczuciu, może po prostu coś źle robiłem) na znajdywaniu kilku istotnych przełączników, wciskaniu ich na oślep i szukaniu drogi do wyjścia, czasem po drodze zastanawiając się, czy skok nad dziurą który właśnie wykonałem był zamierzony i powinienem był go w stanie wykonać.
Do ostatnich 6-7 poziomów musiałem aż się zmusić. Nie czułem się jak w dobrej grze logicznej, gdzie trzeba ruszyć głową, żeby coś osiągnąć, tylko w takim tanim zapychaczu, czym właściwie ta gra jest.

Na papierze koncept fajny, wykonaniu też nic nie mogę zarzucić, ale same łamigłówki... po prostu złe.
Warto? To zależy. Kupić? Co najwyżej na wyprzedaży.

This game struck me as an attempt at artistic expression when I first saw the screenshots. I got all the way to level 30 before I was bored. This game puts the player in an impossible level working with entirely possible physics to solve the puzzle to get to the end of the level. Sadly that's all the game has going for it and it didn't do much with the idea; there's no music and little color in this game to help make solving the puzzle fun, and a bland, blank world to do sadly little in. There is potential in the concept this game used, but it's mostly potential that's gone unused in this game, making this title feel more like some old flash game then a more modern Indy classic.

Évaluation publiée le 21 janvier 2017
Disoriented is a quite short game, but that little bit of time is spent with twenty-four engaging puzzles. The game starts simple, but as more mechanics are gradually introduced, the puzzles get more complex and more difficult. However, the puzzles don't get frustrating, as the mechanics make sense and work together well. The ambient music in the background is a plus, adding to the feel of the game. In my opinion, Disoriented is well worth the $3.99 cost if you're looking for a pure puzzle game.

NOTE: The below section is no longer relevant, as the 600 blank achievements have been removed! However, I'm still keeping it, because I feel my message there is still important.

I have changed my review to "Not Recommended" because the developers of Disoriented have adopted the scummy tactic of adding hundreds of achievements earned extremely easily (in this case, by simply launching the game!) to draw in achivement hunters looking for an easy way to boost their leaderboard ranking. These kinds of achievements make the leaderboard have less meaning and ruin it for everyone else, so I cannot recommend this game in good faith unless the developers remove the offending achievements.

Évaluation publiée le 31 janvier 2017
I purchased Disoriented on sale. I'm a fan of puzzle games and this one seemed to be right up my alley. For the sale price, I figured it would be tough to be disappointed, and pleasantly I am not at all. Gameplay is straight forward with a gradual learning curve. Puzzles are not exceptionally difficult, but are sufficiently rewarding. As some other reviewers have noted, it may benefit from deeper elements, something approaching a story, purpose, or meaning. Additional puzzles beyond those included would also be a strong selling point if included. As is though, I found the game's soundtrack to be peaceful and calming, especially in those moments when I truly was disoriented and in need of unperturbed thought. For the price, it was a nice distraction and I would recommend it for anyone who is a fan of the genre.

1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juin 2018
From what I've read, the developers have done plenty of work post-release to improve Disoriented but nonetheless the game in it's current state is still underwhelming. Its core mechanic of reorienting the player in a 3D, 1st-person space so that what was up is now down or sideways is a very interesting idea and is fundamentally an innovation on one of the oldest puzzle games, the maze. Unfortunately, Reoriented suffers from the main problem that all mazes suffer from and that is the need to trial-and-error your way to the end. This way of playing is one that diminished the "A ha!" moment that all puzzle games must create in order to be fun and it's for this reason that I can't fully recommend Disoriented.

Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2017
Now that the flaw has been removed (see below), I can give a proper review for this game.

This first-person game is a relaxing puzzler that starts out simple and becomes anything but. Despite the fact that there are only a few simple game elements and you can usually see most of the board, it can be a significant challenge to figure out how to get from one place to another.

You'll probably enjoy this more as a game to play every now and then rather than trying to mow through it all at once. The music is airy and relaxing, and the graphics are very simple but effective. If you like challenging visiospatial puzzles and zoning out as you play, I can all but guarantee that you'll enjoy this game for many hours of play.

NOTE: Installing this game used to give you more than 600 blank acheivements, which would ruin the achievement account on your user provile and throw up blank empty boxes on the screen—and no way to get rid of them. Initially the dev did not want to remove them because some people apparently purchased the game solely to 'earn' 600 free achievements. After a lot of complaining (including mine), the dev finally removed the spam achievements, so I'm changing my review from negative to positive because the game itself is relaxing and fun. Props to the dev for fixing a mistake (assuming Steam didn't simply force the change).

Évaluation publiée le 4 aout 2019
See, this game has an interesting idea I guess. There are probably people out there who enjoyed this game.
I myself found the first half quite neat.

But see, I am quite bad at orientation, and this game's name should've been a warning sign for me. I loathed the second half. I just went through it with one guide someone made, because I kept getting confused at what twists what, where goes this or that, where I am... I guess it's kind of the point of the game but I hated it.

See this game has the same aesthetic style as Antichamber. But I finished and enjoyed Antichamber. Antichamber is a game where you do not get lost. There is some semblance of a map, you can clearly see what action has what consequence, the gameplay elements are clearly visible or at least hinted at... This game is just confusing.
Early into the game there are pieces of the terrain you can rotate. It would be fine if these section had some kind of indication, like maybe a seam between the moving and the static part but no, everything is white and flush. Lose your orientation once and you might as well restart.

I did not have fun. I hurt my hand slamming my mouse onto the table out of frustration. This was a waste of time.
At least it was cheap.

If you have a better sense of orientation than me, go for it. I for one strongly disliked the experience.

First 12 levels are easy, then the puzzles finally start getting difficult.

Downside is it started feeling like a walking simulator on some of the puzzles. Puzzles often have a lot of walking between actual actions, which is fine, but mildly obnoxious. Walk speed is a little on the slow side, even with the sprint.

With the amount of camera rotation, it gets disorienting very quickly. Since all the pathways are either white or gray, that also makes it a little tougher. Kinda wish different surfaces would be color coded or something, just to make an easier mental map.

For the price, you really can't go wrong, though.

Évaluation publiée le 2 mai 2019
In short: This is a novel gravity-driven platform-puzzler with smart level design, which rewards formulating plans and thinking ahead. The soothing atmosphere and great interface make it highly enjoyable to play. The pricing more than adequately reflects the total playtime of 3-4 hours.

In long: Your task is to navigate the floating structures of each of the 30 levels in first-person perspective until you reach the door at the end. Walking across curved ramps seamlessly changes gravity. At first the main mechanics are just these ramps and dropping off ledges. Later on knobs to rotate some structures, switches that toggle between light and dark platforms and portals are introduced. These very simple elements are assembled beautifully into complex challenges.
Despite its name I actually didn't find gameplay to be all too disorienting. At any point you can enter view mode, which puts you into third person and allows you to freely rotate the camera. It didn't feel all that useful until I realized you can zoom out with mouse wheel, which gives you pretty much a perfect view of the whole level. You can use this mode to plan your actions, which is an increasingly important aspect as the levels get harder. Since you can and often have to walk off edges, you can totally screw yourself by falling onto a platform from which you cannot escape. This is thankfully mitigated by a brilliant feature allowing you to manually checkpoint whenever you want. When used smartly (i.e. only when you know you're on the right track) you never have to restart a level. Still, this is not a game for mindless trial and error. It pays to pause, really think about a level, calmy formulate a plan and to mentally map out the effects of the various switches in case you need them later on.
With respects to the difficulty the game is not overly hard. The first 10 levels are pretty straight-forward before it admittedly starts getting a bit mind-bendy. While levels might look daunting (the store page screenshots seem to be the most confusing and crowded angles - these levels look simpler in-game), usually the solutions follow a linear path. Complexity does increase, but there are never more than 1 or 2 sensible next steps to actually advance, so I never felt overwhelmed. The hardest steps to figure out are the times when you have to drop down, since there is no obvious indication when to use this mechanic. But once I got used to the "language" of the game, it felt like everything had a fairly logical flow. The first 15 levels took me about 50min. I don't know why, but level 23 gave me considerable difficulty and took me 25min to beat. Everything else was much easier, with later levels ranging from 5-12min. Beating the game on my first play-through took me a little over 3 hours. With just 30 levels the game does feel a bit short, but all the levels are well designed and none felt like filler. I could see myself maybe going back to this game after a few years.

In terms of presentation I would put the game above average. The artsy minimalist low-fi graphics certainly aren't for everyone but after playing for a little while I grew quite fond of them. They're clean and functional. I think it would have been very easy to make this look much worse with texures. There is a nice low-key ambient music through-out. I normally don't like background music in puzzle games, but here it turned out to be really pleasant. The sound effects are decent as well. It all contributes to a very calming, zen-like atmosphere.

On the technical side I was very impressed by the game's low hardware demands. Even though it's a 3D game it runs perfectly on my integrated Intel HD 4000 graphics chip, even with antialiasing. The menu options are truly exemplary: Separate volume sliders with a master slider on top, various graphical options including FOV, mouse sensitivity slider, customizable keyboard controls - I love everything about this! The game starts in full-screen but windowed mode is available. The window is resized by dragging on the edges and the size is remembered across sessions. Well done!

In conclusion I had a lot of fun with this non-conventional puzzle game. The interface and menus are a delight. The levels themselves are interesting and challenging, complex but never overwhelming. I enjoyed mapping out my routes in third person camera mode and then executing them in first person. I'm pretty sure that I never actually deviated from intended solutions, but making precarious drops and touching buttons around corners gave a nice tingly feeling of maybe breaking the rules of the game. The atmosphere is nicely calming. 30 levels of unique content for a playtime of a little over 3 hours is a bit short, but perfectly adequate for the asking price (especially on sale). I can definitely recommend this game for fans of puzzles, rational planning and spatial thinking.

Évaluation publiée le 15 janvier 2017
Disoriented is a simplistic first person view puzzle game, set within a three dimensional abstract bent-space labyrinth environment. The aim of each level is to find the way out. Visually it resembles Antichamber and thematically the upcoming [2017] Manifold Garden, which presumably are the strongest marketing catches Disoriented has on STEAM.

The gameplay to myself feels lacking further challenge or purpose, despite the puzzles growing gradually more tricky and the aim of each stage being clear. Perhaps it is the case of murky "zen" factor. The difficulty curve starts low, therefore if you find the early maps too easy, skip it to the second page. The developer is enganged in the project and responsive, therefore additional contents may eventually be expected.

All in all, if you are keen on puzzlegames and seek something to stretch up your mind, Disoriented may as well be the choice, especially if you are particularly into the first person view style. The score is 6/10 wHATs grade. Recommendable to fanboys of the minimalist design. The price of four Euro is approachable. Nonetheless, if you expect Disoriented to bestow you with a second Antichamber experience, let go of it.

I would also like to point out first person view puzzle games have already been discovered, even the ones featuring bizarre physics.

Nie kłamali w tytule: byłem zdezorientowany przez większość czasu.

W gruncie rzeczy to prosta gra logiczna. Nie ma żadnych specjalnych zdolności, można chodzić i klikać rzeczy. Obracamy elementami, gasimy światło żeby zobaczyć parę nowych, czasem są portale. Tyle. Masz się dostać do wyjścia, znaleźć drogę w tym "labiryncie" złożonym z zawieszonych w powietrzu klocków. A że chodząc po rampach, zmienia się grawitacja, a wszystko widzimy z widoku z pierwszej osoby - jest to bardzo mylące. Zawsze można za to oddalić kamerę i przyjrzeć się całości. Co i tak nie trywializuje sytuacji - początek jest prosty, a czym dalej tym dłużej trzeba kminić. Jest to satysfakcjonujące.

Dość krótkie, nie zawiera nie wiadomo czego... Ale daje satysfakcję z ukończenia, nie jest głupie. I na wyprzedażach kosztuje ledwo ponad 2 złote. Za tyle szkoda nie spróbować.

Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2022
Especially considering the price point, this is a fantastic little puzzle game. It reminds me a lot of another newer title called, Frame of Mind. They share some DNA.

One could arguably say both of them are more artistic experiences than games. However, where they diverge is FoM is a free title that was a student project. Where as this is much more firmly in the game category (though both of them do for sure qualify as games by any measure). This game doesn't really explain itself to you, but it also doesn't really need to. If you just start playing you'll figure it out pretty quickly.

Once you understand how it works, it becomes an exercise in demonstrating logic in conjunction with spatial awareness. If you lack spatial awareness, then I suppose this game will present a challenge will boarder on frustrating. If you have it, or if you are ok with that, then this game is for you. If you need to understand what you are doing and why, then you should probably move along, this one is not for you.

But as for myself, this is great.
 
Nicodemous52

Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2022
It's the 'Dark Souls' of "non-euclid" first person gravitational mazes.
The puzzles, the gimmick of which is mastering the navigation in X Y Z planes and using levers and switches to create new paths, are really good and so is the presentation, where you can certainly feel the touch of Antichamber, with the flowing river and occasional wind bell ambient noises scattered around the sparsely painted area,
but it's very monotonous and occasionally frustrating with the puzzles, as the game doesn't handhold you through certain essential things, like jumping off a ledge (the trick is to never land on a platform without its own U / J-shaped ledge that you can use to 'go back')

I think in this absolute vacuum of the gameplay "roller coaster" design (where developers switch the pace of the action from slow to fast to break the monotony), changing visuals or engaging plot, bundled with some quirky dialogues, achievements are the only thing that can motivate the player to solve all of the puzzles, but when you beat that last of its 30 levels - you'll feel like a million bucks.

빙글빙글 돌아갑니다.
물론 아무곳이나 간다고하여 세상이 돌지는 않고
특정 경로를 따라가면 화면이 그에 맞춰서 빙그르르 돌아가죠.

이를 통해서 도전과제를 위한 젬들을 수집할 수 있는대
처음에 이거를 모두 모아야 문이 열리는건가 하고 모두 수집했는대
딱히 그런 용도는 아니더군요. 정말 도전과제용인듯한...

초반에는 약간의 미로같은 길을 따라가서 문을 통과하면 되지만
특정 경로의 길을 회전시킨다거나 스위치를 통해서 길을 on/off하는 장치도 존재하죠.
그래서 뒤로갈수록 점점 머리가 아파지고 이게 맞는건가하면서 혼란에 빠지기도.

다행이라면 체크 포인트를 자유롭게 설정할 수 있는대
잘못된 길로 갔다가 되돌아돌 수 없는 길로가서 체크 포인트를 해버린다면...

아쉬운 점
-체크 포인트 외에 시간 되돌리기 같은 것도 있다면 괜찮을 것 같음

Évaluation publiée le 14 novembre 2021
PV通りの出口を目指すパズルゲーム。
クリアまでは3～4時間ほどか。

内容としては壁を登って重力が変化するというギミックがメインで、実はそれ以外のギミックはほとんどない。
スイッチを押して足場を移動させるくらいで、やることはめちゃくちゃシンプル。

でもステージはなかなか良く出来ていて無駄がない。
ゴリ押しできそうで出来なかったり、でも飛び降りてみたくなる魅力がある。
状況によっては詰みになるのは仕方ない。

ステージ数は30と少ないのが難点。
この僕が、面白かったのでもうちょっとやりたいと言い出すレベル。

あとはゲーム終了するとセーブデータが消えるバグがあるので一気にクリアすることをおすすめします。

Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2021
3D-Puzzle with a switching perspective etc. I enjoyed the first 15-20 level but than it turned out to be trickier.
A little reminder: If you quit the game, it wont safe your times for each stages.
I want to quote JimDeadlock:
"This is a 3D puzzle game in a similar style to games like The Bridge, Evo Explores and Monument Valley but there are two major differences:

There are no optical illusions - no bridges appear over gaps when obscured, there's no mind-bending twisting of perspective or anything like that, it's all logical and mechanical.

It's a first-person perspective. This makes a big difference in the way you play the levels because you can't get an overall view of the whole puzzle. It's like the difference between solving a maze from above or from within it."

recommend it!

Évaluation publiée le 21 mars 2021
Fun puzzle game, enjoyed my time with it. Not the hardest one in the world, but there were a couple stumpers that required coming back to. It's about 4 hours worth of play on my end. I wasn't speeding through it, and I wasn't following a walkthrough at all. Like I said, I had to come back to at least one of them, but it's the "disorientation" that forms the fundamental weirdness of trying to solve these puzzles.

The more apt you are to thinking in those terms, the faster you'll naturally be able to puzzle through the game; otoh, if that kind of thing makes you sick or your head hurt, then I would advise you to avoid this game.

If you like puzzle games and find the price of this one to be reasonable for ~3-6 hrs of entertainment, I'd say go for it.

Évaluation publiée le 16 janvier 2021
An interesting idea, however it lacks in actually good puzzle mechanics. One is a light switch where you just have to memorize different paths more than actually thinking about where they could help you, one just rotates a part of the map (which is in no way highlighted while it's NOT moving). Both are even the same color so you sometimes don't even know which one is which if you're far away.

This resulted in me not thinking beforehand but just running with it. Most of the time I only had one path to follow and somehow it ended up being the correct one. Some rooms I didn't even understand but got through them on the first try.

More of a memory game than a puzzle game for sure.

TL;DR cool for a new experience, not recommended as a puzzle game. For this money, I liked the new idea.

Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2020
Concept is great. Price is great. I appreciate the minimalistic art style. But I only made it 20 minutes and I'm extremely nauseous now. I feel like I've just had a really, really bad VR experience. Problem is it takes a long time to get over the motion sickness feeling. I couldn't tell what was worse, the free falling when you fell off the walkways or the curved ramps.

Great that you're given the camera system to be able to zoom out and rotate around to help with figuring out your path but you absolutely need a character of some kind to show your current location when you're in the camera mode. Currently you have no idea where you're standing, there's no representation of your character while in this view mode. I think it wasn't put in as it would have taken away from the minimalistic look of the game but even something very faint, doesn't even have to be a person, just some sort of shadow or something to let you know where you were standing would have helped.

...Been well over an hour now after having stopped playing and still have this motion sickness. Terrible.

Check out Manifold Garden instead. Costs a bit more but that one is a masterpiece.

Disoriented，中文意思為迷失方向
遊戲的目標很簡單，就是到達一個關卡的門，但在這之前你會先遇到各種機關阻斷你的路途，你必須要從這些機關中找出規律，並通往門的路。此外在路途中遇到泥土時要種樹，灌溉一定量的樹會有相對應的steam成就。

第一眼看到這遊戲就讓我想到之前很有名的手遊 紀念碑谷（Monument Valley），同樣都是採用莫里茲·柯尼利斯·艾雪（Maurits Cornelis Escher）風格的視覺錯覺Optical illusion的原理來設計關卡。

但是相較於紀念碑谷，這遊戲不但完全沒有劇情，玩家的視角也基本上被困在迷宮裡，看不到全局，到後面的關卡想要破關玩家必須要具備非常好的空間感及方向感，否則就只能每一關都得看攻略。

1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2018
Disoriented is one of these games that I really WANT to be good. Clever Idea, well crafted mechanics, great art style.
But in the end I rage quitted the game for the 3rd time now (this time at level 13 of 30).

The problem lies in information visualization. The game won't show you the effects of pressing a button until you press it. E.g. when you press the light switch (see trailer) you don't know where new bridges might appear and you have to remember the bridges that disappeared yourself. Does not seem like that big of a problem - until you combine it with the changing gravity.

The game game is already hard weird to navigate. So the lack of information leaves you with running around the level remembering it by heart OR brute force your way via trial-and-error.

With a little more information (like the rotatable level parts beeing blue and the "light switch bridges" showing their outlines in gray even when they are inactive), I would have enjoyed the whole game a lot. But sadly I as it is I have to give up on this game again with a headache.

이런 종류의 3D 길찾기 퍼즐 게임은 스토리 위주의 게임과 달리 선형적 구조로 이루어지면 안 된다고 생각한다.
매 스테이지마다 끊임없이 요소를 어떤 순서로 다루어야 하는지 고민하는 데서 재미를 찾을 수 있기 때문이다.

본 게임이 적당히 할 만하다고 생각한 사람이라면 필히 hocus라는 게임을 해 보기를 바람.

Sychon
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 juillet 2017
1. Disoriented will kind of confuse and annoy you from time to time but it provides just enough hot puzzle solving action to be really worth playing if you are a fan of the genre.

2. You will get 660 achievements just for running the game. Thanks, game! I guess this annoys some people though.

3. It is apparently some sort of law that all first person puzzle games be compared to Portal. This is not as good as Portal but I feel saying that is equally as unimportant and meaningless as saying an album of music isn't as good as Pet Sounds.

4. A closer comparison might be Antichamber but this is way less stupid than that game. The rules don't change on you all the time.

5. I got nervous during the first dozen or so levels that this was going to wind up being some sort of walking sim w/ puzzle elements rather than a puzzle game. It's got that beatless synth music that just builds up slowly to nothing and the first few levels are trivial to beat on the first try. Thankfully, those are mostly just a tutorial.

6. It seems likely that the levels in this were designed in the order you play them. The level designs seem to get better as the game goes on. At some point, they released six new levels to add to the original game and those are astronomically better than the levels before it.

7. The name of the game is Disoriented, I get it but I feel like the devs should have done more to let you know where you are and what's going on. The gravity flipping mechanic this is build on is great but every level is solid plain white and gray and it's really hard to tell one section of the level from another. Every switch in the game is blue and there are frequently three or more identical switches in a level and it can get to be a real brain bender just to remember what switch does what. It feels like they could have used kept the overall look and feel of the game and still given you an indication of which switch you should be trying to get to to move a certain section.

8. I wouldn't say this gave me motion sickness or anything but every now and then after an hour or so of playing, I'd be like, "You know what, my eyes and brain need a break" and have to put it down for the day.

9. Most of the levels can be beaten in a matter of minutes if you know the solution but more than a couple of them took me over a half hour to solve. Sometimes, this was a result of good puzzle design. Other times, it was a result of me being, well, disoriented.

10. The issues discussed in 7 make it kind of hard to partially solve a level and come back to it later. Every thing is a sea of white. Nothing really sticks in the head so you can remember where you were or what you did.

11. There is no plot to this game whatever.

12. I will admit I looked up the answers to a few of these puzzles. To their credit, never once did I have a "I didn't even know I could do that" moment when doing this. The solutions were always right there in front of me, I just didn't see them. This is good.

13. I sincerely figured I'd pick up and finish this game in one sitting due to the low price and the play times on most reviews here but it's really a much more meaty experience than that. There's no real replay value in this unless you want to speed run it for some reason but this is an game you'll need some time to dig into--and it's worth it once you do.
 
LogicalFrank
